modules.title: Lab Environment Setup
modules.description: Set up VirtualBox, Kali Linux, and Windows environments for ethical hacking practice

lessons.title: VirtualBox Installation
lessons.description: Install and configure VirtualBox for virtualization

content.title: Introduction
content.content: VirtualBox is a free virtualization platform that allows you to run multiple operating systems on a single machine. This is essential for ethical hacking practice as it provides isolated environments.

content.title: Download VirtualBox
content.content: Visit the official VirtualBox website and download the latest version for your operating system.

content.title: Installation Command (Linux)
content.content: sudo apt update && sudo apt install virtualbox virtualbox-ext-pack

modules.title: Windows Command Line Footprinting
modules.description: Learn footprinting basics using Windows command line tools like ping, nslookup, and tracert

lessons.title: Ping Command Fundamentals
lessons.description: Master the ping command for network reconnaissance

content.title: What is Ping?
content.content: The ping command sends ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) packets to test the reachability of a host and measures round-trip time.

content.title: Basic Ping Command
content.content: ping www.certifiedhacker.com

content.title: Expected Output
content.content:
Reply from 162.241.216.11: bytes=32 time=160ms TTL=40
Reply from 162.241.216.11: bytes=32 time=151ms TTL=40
Reply from 162.241.216.11: bytes=32 time=151ms TTL=40
Reply from 162.241.216.11: bytes=32 time=153ms TTL=40

Ping statistics for 162.241.216.11:
    Packets: Sent = 4, Received = 4, Lost = 0 (0% loss)
Approximate round trip times in milli-seconds:
    Minimum = 151ms, Maximum = 160ms, Average = 153ms

lessons.title: Maximum Frame Size Discovery
lessons.description: Find the maximum frame size on the network using ping

content.title: Frame Size Concept
content.content: Network frames have maximum transmission unit (MTU) limits. We can discover this using ping with the don't fragment flag.

content.title: Test Frame Size
content.content: ping www.certifiedhacker.com -f -l 1500

content.title: Fragmentation Error
content.content: Packet needs to be fragmented but DF set.

content.title: Finding Maximum Size
content.content: Try different values until you find the maximum frame size that works without fragmentation. Start with 1472 bytes and adjust accordingly.

lessons.title: TTL Investigation
lessons.description: Understand Time to Live values and their significance

content.title: What is TTL?
content.content: Time to Live (TTL) is a mechanism that limits the lifespan of data in a network. When TTL reaches 0, routers discard the packet to prevent infinite loops.

content.title: Set TTL Value
content.content: ping www.certifiedhacker.com -i 3

content.title: TTL Expired Response
content.content:
Reply from 10.10.127.254: TTL expired in transit.
Reply from 10.10.127.254: TTL expired in transit.
Reply from 10.10.127.254: TTL expired in transit.

lessons.title: Traceroute Analysis
lessons.description: Trace the path packets take to reach their destination

content.title: Traceroute Purpose
content.content: Traceroute shows the path packets take through the network to reach their destination, revealing intermediate routers and network topology.

content.title: Windows Traceroute
content.content: tracert www.certifiedhacker.com

content.title: Analyzing Results
content.content: Each line in the traceroute output represents a hop. The number of hops tells you how many routers the packet passes through to reach its destination.

modules.title: Packet Crafting with hping3
modules.description: Learn UDP and TCP packet crafting techniques using hping3 for network testing

lessons.title: hping3 Fundamentals
lessons.description: Introduction to hping3 and basic packet crafting

content.title: What is hping3?
content.content: hping3 is a scriptable packet crafting tool that uses the Tcl language. It allows you to create custom network packets for testing network devices and discovering vulnerabilities.

content.title: Basic hping3 Command
content.content: hping3 -c 3 <Target IP address>

content.title: Understanding Parameters
content.content: The -c parameter stands for packet count, meaning we only want to send three packets to the target machine.

content.title: SYN Flag Scan with Port Range
content.content: hping3 --scan 1-3000 -S <Target IP address>

lessons.title: UDP Packet Crafting
lessons.description: Create and send custom UDP packets

content.title: UDP Packet Crafting
content.content: hping3 <Target IP address> --udp --rand-source --data 500

content.title: Parameter Explanation
content.content:
--udp: UDP mode
--rand-source: Random source address
--data: Data size in bytes

content.title: Analysis with Wireshark
content.content: Use Wireshark on the target machine to capture and analyze the UDP packets. Look for the Data (500 bytes) section in the packet details.

lessons.title: TCP SYN Requests
lessons.description: Send TCP SYN requests to specific ports

content.title: TCP SYN Request
content.content: hping3 -S <Target IP address> -p 80 -c 5

content.title: Parameter Breakdown
content.content:
-S: TCP SYN request
-p: Target port (80 in this example)
-c: Packet count (5 packets)

lessons.title: TCP Flooding Technique
lessons.description: Perform TCP flooding for testing purposes

content.title: Legal Warning
content.content: TCP flooding should only be performed in controlled lab environments with proper authorization. Unauthorized flooding is illegal and unethical.

content.title: TCP Flood Command
content.content: hping3 <Target IP address> --flood

content.title: Flood Parameter
content.content: The --flood parameter sends packets as fast as possible without waiting for replies. This can overwhelm the target system's resources.

modules.title: DoS Attack Detection
modules.description: Detect and analyze DoS attacks using KFSensor and Wireshark

lessons.title: KFSensor Configuration
lessons.description: Set up KFSensor honeypot for DoS detection

content.title: About KFSensor
content.content: KFSensor is a Windows-based honeypot IDS that acts as a decoy server to attract and detect hackers and worms by simulating vulnerable system services.

content.title: Required Tools
content.content:
• Install KFSensor on Windows 10
• Install Wireshark for packet analysis
• Ensure Kali Linux is available for attack simulation

content.title: Configuration Steps
content.content:
1. Launch KFSensor as Administrator
2. Click Settings → Set Up Wizard
3. Select 'Cautious' from DoS Options
4. Enable 'packet dump files' from Network Protocol Analyzer

lessons.title: DoS Attack Simulation
lessons.description: Perform controlled DoS attack for detection testing

content.title: Check Target Port
content.content: nmap -p 21 <Windows 10 IP address>

content.title: SYN Flooding Attack
content.content: hping3 -d 100 -S -p 21 --flood <Windows 10 IP Address>

content.title: Attack Parameters
content.content:
-S: SYN Flooding
-p 21: Target FTP port
-d 100: Data size per packet (100 bytes)
--flood: Maximum speed flooding

content.title: Observing Impact
content.content: During the attack, the Windows machine may become unresponsive due to resource exhaustion. This demonstrates the effectiveness of the DoS attack.

lessons.title: Attack Detection and Analysis
lessons.description: Analyze detected attacks using KFSensor and Wireshark

content.title: KFSensor Detection
content.content: After the attack, KFSensor will show the FTP icon changing to red, indicating detected attack traffic. Look for events labeled 'DOS Attack' in the event log.

content.title: Event Details
content.content: Double-click events to view details including severity level (High), event description (Syn Scan), visitor IP address (attacker), and sensor name (FTP).

content.title: Wireshark Packet Analysis
content.content: Packet dump files are stored in C:\kfsensor\dumps by default. Open these files in Wireshark to analyze packet headers, source IP addresses, and attack patterns.

modules.title: njRAT Remote Access Trojan
modules.description: Understand njRAT capabilities and remote access techniques

lessons.title: njRAT Capabilities Overview
lessons.description: Understanding the features and capabilities of njRAT

content.title: What is njRAT?
content.content: njRAT is a Remote Access Trojan with powerful data-stealing capabilities. It can log keystrokes, access cameras, steal browser credentials, manipulate files, and provide complete remote desktop access.

content.title: RAT Capabilities
content.content:
RATs allow attackers to:
• Remotely access complete GUI
• Control victim's computer without awareness
• Perform screenshot and camera capture
• Execute code and shell commands
• Access files and manipulate processes
• Log keystrokes and passwords
• Manage Windows registry

content.title: Infection Vectors
content.content:
njRAT typically spreads through:
• Phishing email attachments
• Drive-by downloads from malicious websites
• Infected USB drives
• Network file shares
• Social engineering attacks

lessons.title: Creating njRAT Server
lessons.description: Build and configure njRAT server executable

content.title: Launch njRAT
content.content: Start njRAT on the attacker machine (Windows 10). A GUI will appear with a popup asking for the port number for target communication.

content.title: Port Configuration
content.content: Use the default port 5552 and click Start to begin listening for incoming connections from infected targets.

content.title: Access Builder
content.content: Click the 'Builder' button in the lower-left corner to access the server creation interface.

content.title: Server Configuration
content.content:
In the Builder dialog:
1. Enter the attacker machine's IP address
2. Check 'Copy to StartUp and Registry StartUp' for persistence
3. Click 'Build' to create the executable
4. Save as 'Example.exe' on the desktop

lessons.title: Remote Control Capabilities
lessons.description: Explore various remote control features of njRAT

content.title: File System Access
content.content: Right-click the connected target and select 'Manager' to access the file system. Navigate directories and perform operations like copy, delete, rename, and execute files.

content.title: Process Management
content.content: Access 'Process Manager' to view running processes. Right-click any process to Kill, Delete, or Restart it, giving complete control over target system processes.

content.title: Connection Management
content.content: Use the 'Connections' menu to view active network connections. Kill specific connections between communicating machines through particular ports.

content.title: Registry Manipulation
content.content: Access the Windows Registry through the 'Registry' menu. Navigate registry hives and modify registry keys and values for system manipulation.

content.title: Remote Command Shell
content.content: Launch 'Remote Shell' to get a command prompt on the target machine. Execute any command-line operations remotely.

lessons.title: Surveillance and Monitoring
lessons.description: Use njRAT's surveillance capabilities

content.title: Remote Desktop Access
content.content: Select 'Remote Desktop Connection' to view and interact with the target's desktop in real-time using mouse and keyboard input.

content.title: Camera and Microphone
content.content: Access 'Remote Cam' and 'Microphone' options to spy on the target through their webcam and record audio conversations.

content.title: Keylogger Functionality
content.content: Use the 'Keylogger' option to capture all keystrokes performed by the target, including passwords, messages, and sensitive information.

content.title: Persistence Mechanism
content.content: njRAT maintains persistence through startup and registry entries. Even if the victim restarts the machine, the RAT will automatically reconnect upon login.

modules.title: Disk Analysis with hdparm and dd
modules.description: Learn disk analysis techniques using hdparm, dd, and hexedit for forensic investigations

lessons.title: hdparm Fundamentals
lessons.description: Introduction to hdparm for disk information gathering

content.title: What is hdparm?
content.content: hdparm provides a command line interface to various kernel interfaces supported by the Linux SATA/PATA/SAS libata subsystem and older IDE driver subsystem.

content.title: Install hdparm (Ubuntu)
content.content: sudo apt-get install -y hdparm

content.title: Get Disk Information
content.content: hdparm -giI /dev/sda

content.title: Parameter Meanings
content.content:
-g: Display drive geometry (cylinders, heads, sectors)
-i: Show identification info from boot/config time
-I: Display detailed identification information

lessons.title: Data Duplication with dd
lessons.description: Master the dd command for disk imaging and data manipulation

content.title: Understanding dd
content.content: The dd command allows direct reading and writing from/to different files. It's essential for disk imaging, data recovery, and forensic analysis.

content.title: Create Working Directory
content.content: mkdir /CaseStudies && cd /CaseStudies

content.title: Create Sample File
content.content: dd if=/dev/zero of=/CaseStudies/sample.dd bs=1M count=1

content.title: Disk Sanitization
content.content: dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/sdb bs=4K conv=noerror,sync

content.title: Create Disk Copy
content.content: dd if=/CaseStudies/sample.dd bs=4k of=/CaseStudies/copy.dd

lessons.title: Hex Analysis with hexedit
lessons.description: Analyze binary data using hexedit

content.title: Install hexedit
content.content: dnf -y install hexedit

content.title: Using hexedit
content.content: hexedit shows files in both ASCII and hexadecimal format. It's useful for inspecting binary files, executables, and raw disk data.

content.title: Edit Sample File
content.content: hexedit sample.dd

content.title: View Hex Data
content.content: dd bs=512 skip=256 count=1 if=/CaseStudies/sample.dd | xxd

modules.title: Windows Network Sniffing Tools
modules.description: Comprehensive guide to Windows-based network analysis and sniffing tools

lessons.title: Wireshark Network Analysis
lessons.description: Master Wireshark for network protocol analysis

content.title: About Wireshark
content.content: Wireshark is the world's foremost network protocol analyzer. It allows you to see network traffic at a microscopic level and is the standard for network analysis across enterprises and educational institutions.

content.title: Key Capabilities
content.content:
• Deep inspection of hundreds of protocols
• Live capture and offline analysis
• Rich VoIP analysis
• Powerful display filters
• Cross-platform compatibility
• Decrypt protocols like WEP, WPA/WPA2

content.title: Basic Capture Process
content.content:
1. Select network interface
2. Start capture
3. Apply display filters
4. Analyze packet details
5. Follow TCP/UDP streams
6. Export relevant data

lessons.title: Cain & Abel Password Recovery
lessons.description: Password cracking and network sniffing with Cain & Abel

content.title: Cain & Abel Overview
content.content: Cain & Abel is a password recovery tool for Microsoft Windows. It can recover passwords through dictionary attacks, brute force, cryptanalysis attacks, and network packet sniffing.

content.title: Key Features
content.content:
• Password recovery for various applications
• Network password sniffing
• ARP poisoning attacks
• Dictionary and brute force attacks
• Cryptanalysis capabilities
• VoIP conversation recording

content.title: Ethical Usage
content.content: Cain & Abel should only be used for legitimate security testing with proper authorization. Unauthorized password cracking is illegal and unethical.

lessons.title: Additional Sniffing Tools
lessons.description: Overview of other important Windows sniffing tools

content.title: SMAC - MAC Address Changer
content.content: SMAC is a powerful MAC address spoofing tool that can activate new MAC addresses automatically after changing them. Useful for bypassing MAC-based security controls.

content.title: Capsa Network Analyzer
content.content: Capsa Free provides network monitoring, troubleshooting, and analysis capabilities. It offers real-time network monitoring and helps identify network problems and security issues.

content.title: OmniPeek Network Analyzer
content.content: OmniPeek provides real-time analysis for various network segments including 802.11 wireless networks and voice/video over IP traffic with advanced protocol analysis.

content.title: XArp - ARP Spoofing Detection
content.content: XArp detects ARP-based attacks using active and passive detection modules. It protects against ARP spoofing attacks that firewalls and operating systems cannot detect.

modules.title: Advanced Network Sniffing Tools
modules.description: Comprehensive guide to Windows-based network analysis and sniffing tools

lessons.title: Wireshark Network Protocol Analyzer
lessons.description: Master the world's foremost network protocol analyzer

content.title: What is Wireshark?
content.content: Wireshark is the world's foremost and widely-used network protocol analyzer. It lets you see what's happening on your network at a microscopic level and is the de facto standard across many commercial and non-profit enterprises, government agencies, and educational institutions.

content.title: Installation
content.content:
Download Wireshark from the official website: https://www.wireshark.org/

Wireshark is available for Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms.

content.title: Basic Packet Capture
content.content:
Wireshark allows you to:
• Capture live network traffic
• Analyze protocol details
• Filter specific traffic patterns
• Export capture data for analysis
• Decode encrypted protocols

lessons.title: Cain & Abel Password Recovery
lessons.description: Learn password decryption and decoding techniques

content.title: Cain & Abel Overview
content.content: Cain & Abel is a security tool for decryption and decoding of passwords for offline programs and network services. It features powerful decoding algorithms and extensive decrypting tools.

content.title: Tool Capabilities
content.content:
Cain & Abel can recover passwords for:
• Network sniffing and ARP poisoning
• Cracking encrypted passwords using dictionary attacks
• Recording VoIP conversations
• Decoding scrambled passwords
• Revealing password boxes

content.title: Download Information
content.content:
Download from: https://www.filehorse.com/download-cain-and-abel/

Note: This tool should only be used for legitimate security testing purposes.

lessons.title: SMAC MAC Address Changer
lessons.description: Learn MAC address spoofing techniques

content.title: SMAC Tool Overview
content.content: SMAC is a powerful and easy-to-use tool for MAC address changing (spoofing). The tool can activate a new MAC address right after changing it automatically.

content.title: MAC Spoofing Applications
content.content:
MAC address spoofing is used for:
• Bypassing MAC-based access controls
• Network troubleshooting
• Privacy enhancement
• Security testing
• Network analysis

content.title: Download SMAC
content.content:
Available at: https://smac.soft32.com/

SMAC provides an easy graphical interface for changing MAC addresses on Windows systems.

modules.title: TCPDump Network Packet Analysis
modules.description: Master the premier command-line network analysis tool for packet capture and analysis

lessons.title: TCPDump Fundamentals
lessons.description: Learn basic TCPDump commands and options

content.title: What is TCPDump?
content.content: TCPDump is a data-network packet analyzer that runs under a command line interface. It allows users to display TCP/IP and other packets being transmitted or received over a network. TCPDump is the premier network analysis tool providing both power and simplicity.

content.title: Essential Command Options
content.content:
Key TCPDump options:
• -i any: Listen on all interfaces
• -n: Don't resolve hostnames
• -nn: Don't resolve hostnames or port names
• -X: Show packet contents in hex and ASCII
• -v, -vv, -vvv: Increase verbosity
• -c: Capture specific number of packets
• -s: Define capture size (use -s0 for everything)

content.title: Basic Communication Capture
content.content: tcpdump -nS

content.title: Verbose Capture
content.content: tcpdump -nnvvS

lessons.title: Reading TCPDump Output
lessons.description: Understand TCP and UDP packet structure in TCPDump output

content.title: TCP Field Breakdown
content.content:
TCP packet components:
• Timestamp: 19:10:23.857236
• Protocol: IP
• Source: 10.0.10.107:39643
• Destination: 10.0.10.102:wap-wsp
• Flags: [P.] = PUSH + ACK
• Sequence numbers: seq 1330613859:1330614161
• Acknowledgment: ack 2667667222
• Window size: win 6142
• Length: 302 bytes

content.title: UDP Packet Structure
content.content:
Example UDP output:
13:38:54.920116 IP 10.0.10.107.17500 > 10.0.10.1.17500: UDP, length 103

UDP is simpler than TCP with just timestamp, source/destination addresses and ports, protocol type, and length.

lessons.title: Advanced Filtering and Expressions
lessons.description: Use expressions to filter specific traffic types

content.title: Expression Types
content.content:
TCPDump supports three expression types:
• Type: host, net, port
• Direction: src, dst, src or dst, src and dst
• Protocol: tcp, udp, icmp

content.title: Filter by Host
content.content: tcpdump host 8.8.8.8

content.title: Source Traffic Only
content.content: tcpdump src 8.8.8.8

content.title: ICMP Traffic Only
content.content: tcpdump icmp

content.title: Capture Two ICMP Packets
content.content: tcpdump -nnvXSs 0 -c2 icmp

modules.title: Digital Forensics: File Recovery
modules.description: Learn file carving and recovery techniques using forensic tools

lessons.title: File Carving Fundamentals
lessons.description: Understanding file carving principles and applications

content.title: What is File Carving?
content.content: File carving is a process used in computer forensics to extract data from a disk drive or storage device without the assistance of the file system. It recovers files at unallocated space without file information and is used to recover data for digital forensic investigations.

content.title: How File Carving Works
content.content: File carving works on raw data and is independent of file system structure. When a file is deleted in FAT file system, the file's directory entry becomes unallocated space, but the file data remains unchanged until overwritten. Carving tools use file headers and footers to identify and extract files.

content.title: Forensic Applications
content.content:
File carving is essential for:
• Recovering deleted evidence
• Analyzing damaged storage devices
• Extracting data from unallocated space
• Digital crime investigations
• Data breach analysis

lessons.title: Setting Up Test Environment
lessons.description: Create a forensic test environment with sample data

content.title: Create Forensic Directory
content.content: mkdir forensic && cd /forensic/

content.title: Create Virtual Hard Drive
content.content: dd if=/dev/zero bs=1M count=100 of=/forensic/disk.img

content.title: Set Up Loop Device
content.content: losetup /dev/loop0 /forensic/disk.img

content.title: Create ext4 Filesystem
content.content: mkfs.ext4 /dev/loop0

content.title: Mount Filesystem
content.content: mkdir /mnt/disk/ && mount -o loop /forensic/disk.img /mnt/disk/

content.title: Download Sample Files
content.content:
cd /mnt/disk/
curl -O https://www.photos-public-domain.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/gray-cat-with-green-eyes.jpg
curl -O https://www.photos-public-domain.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/orange-and-white-cat-in-window-sill.jpg

lessons.title: File Recovery with Scalpel
lessons.description: Use Scalpel for automated file carving

content.title: Install Scalpel
content.content: sudo apt-get install scalpel -y

content.title: Copy Configuration File
content.content:
mkdir /forensic/case && cd /forensic/case
cp /etc/scalpel.conf /forensic/case/

content.title: Configure Scalpel
content.content:
Edit scalpel.conf to uncomment the jpg configuration line:
# JPG format files
jpg    y    200000    \xff\xd8\xff\xe0\x00\x10    \xff\xd9

content.title: Run Scalpel Recovery
content.content: scalpel -c scalpel.conf /forensic/disk.img

content.title: View Recovery Results
content.content: ls -R /forensic/case/scalpel-output

lessons.title: File Recovery with Foremost
lessons.description: Alternative file carving using Foremost tool

content.title: Install Foremost
content.content: sudo apt-get install foremost -y

content.title: Foremost Overview
content.content: Foremost recovers files using their headers, footers, and data structures. It's designed to ignore the file system structure and work at the block level.

content.title: Run Foremost Recovery
content.content: foremost -t jpg -o foremost-output /forensic/disk.img

content.title: View Foremost Results
content.content: ls -lR foremost-output/

content.title: Analyze Audit File
content.content: Check the audit.txt file in the output directory for detailed recovery statistics and file information.

modules.title: Partition Recovery Forensics
modules.description: Learn to recover deleted partitions using forensic tools

lessons.title: Creating and Deleting Test Partition
lessons.description: Set up a test scenario for partition recovery

content.title: Create New Partition
content.content: fdisk /dev/sdb

content.title: Partition Creation Steps
content.content:
In fdisk:
1. Press 'n' for new partition
2. Select 'p' for primary
3. Accept default partition number (1)
4. Accept default first sector
5. Accept default last sector
6. Press 'w' to write changes

content.title: Create ext4 Filesystem
content.content: mkfs.ext4 /dev/sdb1

content.title: Mount and Add Data
content.content:
mkdir /mnt/flashdrive
mount /dev/sdb1 /mnt/flashdrive
cd /mnt/flashdrive

content.title: Download Sample Files
content.content: curl -O https://www.photos-public-domain.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/gray-cat-with-green-eyes.jpg

content.title: Delete the Partition
content.content:
Unmount the filesystem and use fdisk to delete the partition:
1. umount /mnt/flashdrive
2. fdisk /dev/sdb
3. Press 'd' to delete partition
4. Press 'w' to write changes

lessons.title: Forensic Imaging with dcfldd
lessons.description: Create forensic copies using dcfldd

content.title: Install dcfldd
content.content: sudo apt-get install dcfldd -y

content.title: dcfldd Overview
content.content: dcfldd is an enhanced version of dd for forensics and security. It provides built-in hashing, progress reporting, and error handling specifically designed for forensic imaging.

content.title: Create Case Directory
content.content: mkdir -p /forensic/case && cd /forensic/case

content.title: Create Evidence Copy with Hash
content.content: dcfldd if=/dev/sdb of=flashdrive.dd hash=md5 hashlog=flashdrive.md5

content.title: Verify Image Integrity
content.content: The hashlog file contains MD5 hashes to verify the integrity of the forensic image. This ensures the evidence hasn't been tampered with during the imaging process.

lessons.title: Partition Analysis and Recovery
lessons.description: Analyze and recover the deleted partition

content.title: Analyze Partition Table
content.content: fdisk -l flashdrive.dd

content.title: Calculate Partition Offset
content.content:
Use the start sector information from fdisk to calculate the byte offset:
Offset = Start Sector × 512 bytes

Example: If start sector is 2048:
Offset = 2048 × 512 = 1,048,576 bytes

content.title: Mount Recovered Partition
content.content: mount -o ro,loop,offset=1048576 flashdrive.dd /mnt/flashdrive/

content.title: Verify File Recovery
content.content: ls -lia /mnt/flashdrive/*.jpg

content.title: Recovery Verification
content.content: If files are visible with proper inode numbers, the partition recovery was successful. The data was preserved even after partition deletion because only the partition table was modified, not the actual data.

modules.title: ExifTool Metadata Analysis
modules.description: Extract and analyze metadata from various file types using ExifTool

lessons.title: ExifTool Fundamentals
lessons.description: Understanding metadata and ExifTool capabilities

content.title: What is Metadata?
content.content: Metadata is data about data. In digital files, metadata contains information about the file's creation, modification, location, camera settings, software used, and much more. This information can be valuable for digital forensics and OSINT investigations.

content.title: ExifTool Overview
content.content: ExifTool is a platform-independent Perl library plus command-line application for reading, writing, and editing meta information in a wide variety of files. It supports many metadata formats including EXIF, GPS, IPTC, XMP, JFIF, and more.

content.title: Supported File Types
content.content:
ExifTool works with:
• Image files (JPEG, TIFF, PNG, RAW formats)
• Document files (PDF, DOC, DOCX, XLS, XLSX)
• Video files (MP4, AVI, MOV)
• Audio files (MP3, FLAC, WAV)
• Many camera-specific formats

lessons.title: Document Metadata Analysis
lessons.description: Extract metadata from office documents

content.title: Download Sample Document
content.content: curl -O https://www.interpol.int/content/download/13927/file/WOA%20database%20application%20form.docx

content.title: Extract Document Metadata
content.content: exiftool interpol.docx

content.title: Document Metadata Information
content.content:
Document metadata reveals:
• Author information
• Creation and modification dates
• Software version used
• Company information
• Document revision history
• Template information
• Total editing time

content.title: Privacy Implications
content.content: Document metadata can reveal sensitive information about the creator, organization, and document history. Always sanitize metadata before sharing sensitive documents.

lessons.title: Image Metadata and GPS Analysis
lessons.description: Extract location and camera data from images

content.title: Download Sample Image
content.content:
curl -O https://exiftool.org/Xiaomi.tar.gz
tar -xf xiaomi.tar.gz
cd ~/Xiaomi/

content.title: Extract Image Metadata
content.content: exiftool XiaomiMiA2Lite.jpg

content.title: GPS Location Data
content.content:
Image metadata can contain:
• GPS coordinates (latitude/longitude)
• Altitude information
• Camera make and model
• Camera settings (ISO, aperture, shutter speed)
• Date and time of capture
• Software used for processing

content.title: Location Privacy Concerns
content.content: GPS metadata in images can reveal exact locations where photos were taken. This poses privacy and security risks, especially for sensitive locations or personal safety.

modules.title: Network Packet Dissection
modules.description: Deep analysis of TCP, ICMP, and ARP packet structures

lessons.title: Internet Protocol Packet Types
lessons.description: Understanding different packet types and their characteristics

content.title: Packet Type Selection
content.content: The Internet Protocol offers several packet protocols ranging from very fast to very reliable. Each layer has evolved to solve specific problems. To select the correct packet type, you must understand what you're transmitting and the reliability requirements.

content.title: Packet Type Comparison
content.content:
Key differences:

**Raw Packets:**
• Overhead: 20-60 bytes
• Message Size: 65,535 bytes
• Reliability: Low
• Throughput: High

**TCP Packets:**
• Overhead: 20-60 + 20-60 bytes
• Message Size: Unlimited
• Reliability: High
• Throughput: Low
• Stream-based

**UDP Packets:**
• Overhead: 20-60 + 8 bytes
• Message Size: 65,535 bytes
• Reliability: Low
• Throughput: Medium
• Datagram-based

content.title: When to Use Each Protocol
content.content:
**TCP:** Use for reliable data transfer (web browsing, file transfer, email)
**UDP:** Use for real-time applications (video streaming, gaming, DNS)
**ICMP:** Use for network diagnostics (ping, traceroute)
**Raw:** Use for custom protocols or network tools

lessons.title: ICMP Packet Structure Analysis
lessons.description: Detailed breakdown of ICMP packet components

content.title: Capture ICMP Packets
content.content: tcpdump -nnvvXXS -s0 -c2 icmp

content.title: ICMP Packet Structure
content.content:
Example ICMP packet:
aa20 66d2 5364 ca3b cc0e 1069 0800 4500
0054 9764 0000 4001 e1ef c0a8 4003 c0a8
4001 0000 3534 180d 0000 601a d934 0002

**Ethernet Header (14 bytes):**
• MAC Destination: aa20 66d2 5364
• MAC Source: ca3b cc0e 1069
• EtherType: 0800 (IPv4)

content.title: IP Header Analysis
content.content:
**IP Header (20 bytes):**
• Version: 4 (IPv4)
• Header Length: 5 (20 bytes)
• Type of Service: 00
• Total Length: 0054 (84 bytes)
• Identification: 9764
• Flags: 0 (no fragmentation)
• TTL: 40 (64 decimal)
• Protocol: 01 (ICMP)
• Header Checksum: e1ef
• Source IP: c0a8 4003 (192.168.64.3)
• Destination IP: c0a8 4001 (192.168.64.1)

content.title: ICMP Data Analysis
content.content:
**ICMP Header and Data:**
• Type: 00 (Echo Reply)
• Code: 00 (Default)
• Checksum: 3534
• Identifier: 180d
• Sequence Number: 0000
• Data: Timestamp and padding bytes

lessons.title: TCP vs UDP Packet Analysis
lessons.description: Compare TCP and UDP packet structures

content.title: Capture TCP Packets
content.content: tcpdump -nnvvXXS -s0 -c5 tcp

content.title: Capture UDP Packets
content.content: tcpdump -nnvvXXS -s0 -c5 udp

content.title: TCP Header Fields
content.content:
TCP includes additional fields for reliability:
• Sequence Numbers: Track data order
• Acknowledgment Numbers: Confirm receipt
• Window Size: Flow control
• Flags: Control connection state
• Options: Additional TCP features

content.title: UDP Simplicity
content.content:
UDP header contains only:
• Source Port (2 bytes)
• Destination Port (2 bytes)
• Length (2 bytes)
• Checksum (2 bytes)

Total UDP overhead: 8 bytes vs TCP's 20+ bytes

content.title: Performance Implications
content.content:
**TCP Reliability Cost:**
• Higher overhead
• Connection establishment
• Acknowledgments and retransmissions
• Flow control mechanisms

**UDP Speed Benefits:**
• Minimal overhead
• No connection setup
• Fire-and-forget delivery
• No built-in error recovery

modules.title: Malware Obfuscation Techniques
modules.description: Learn about malware obfuscation using crypters and evasion techniques

lessons.title: Understanding Malware Obfuscation
lessons.description: Learn the principles and purposes of malware obfuscation

content.title: What is a Crypter?
content.content: A Crypter is software used to hide viruses, keyloggers, or RAT tools from antiviruses so they are not detected and deleted. It assigns hidden values to each individual code within the source code, making the source hidden and difficult for AV tools to scan.

content.title: Common Obfuscation Techniques
content.content:
Malware authors use various techniques:
• Code encryption and packing
• Anti-debugging measures
• Virtual machine detection
• Polymorphic code generation
• Dead code insertion
• Control flow obfuscation

content.title: AV Evasion Strategies
content.content:
Crypters work by:
• Encrypting the malicious payload
• Using legitimate-looking wrapper code
• Implementing runtime decryption
• Avoiding known malicious signatures
• Using metamorphic techniques

content.title: Ethical and Legal Considerations
content.content: This information is for educational and defensive purposes only. Creating or distributing malware is illegal and unethical. Security professionals should understand these techniques to better defend against them.

lessons.title: Malware Detection Analysis
lessons.description: Analyze detection rates before and after obfuscation

content.title: Baseline Detection Testing
content.content: Before obfuscation, upload test malware to scanning services like VirusTotal to establish baseline detection rates. Record the number of engines that detect the sample.

content.title: Online Scanning Services
content.content:
Popular malware scanning services:
• VirusTotal (virustotal.com)
• Hybrid Analysis (hybrid-analysis.com)
• Any.run (any.run)
• Joe Sandbox (joesandbox.com)

Note: Never upload actual malware to public services

content.title: Detection Rate Analysis
content.content:
Key metrics to track:
• Number of engines detecting
• Detection names and categories
• Behavioral analysis results
• Static vs dynamic detection
• Time to detection

content.title: Measuring Evasion Success
content.content:
After applying obfuscation techniques, measure:
• Reduction in detection rate
• Changes in detection names
• Delay in detection time
• Persistence of evasion over time

lessons.title: Defending Against Obfuscated Malware
lessons.description: Learn defensive techniques against obfuscated threats

content.title: Behavioral Detection
content.content:
Modern defenses focus on behavior:
• Monitor system calls and API usage
• Analyze network communication patterns
• Track file system modifications
• Monitor registry changes
• Detect anomalous process behavior

content.title: Sandbox Analysis
content.content:
Sandbox environments provide:
• Isolated execution environment
• Dynamic behavior monitoring
• Network traffic analysis
• System change tracking
• Safe malware analysis

content.title: Proactive Threat Hunting
content.content:
Hunt for indicators of compromise:
• Unusual network connections
• Suspicious process relationships
• Unexpected file modifications
• Registry persistence mechanisms
• Memory injection techniques

content.title: Layered Defense Approach
content.content:
Implement multiple defense layers:
• Endpoint detection and response (EDR)
• Network monitoring and analysis
• User behavior analytics
• Threat intelligence integration
• Regular security awareness training

modules.title: MAC Address Spoofing Techniques
modules.description: Learn MAC address spoofing for anonymity and network testing

lessons.title: Understanding MAC Address Spoofing
lessons.description: Learn the principles and applications of MAC address spoofing

content.title: What is MAC Spoofing?
content.content: MAC spoofing is a technique for changing a factory-assigned Media Access Control (MAC) address of a network interface. While the hardware MAC address cannot be changed, many drivers allow the operating system to use a different MAC address.

content.title: Why Change MAC Address?
content.content:
MAC address spoofing is used for:
• Increasing anonymity and privacy
• Impersonating other devices
• Bypassing MAC-based access filters
• Network troubleshooting
• Penetration testing
• Avoiding device tracking

content.title: Limitations and Considerations
content.content:
MAC spoofing only affects the local network segment. It cannot bypass:
• Router-level filtering
• Internet-based tracking
• Higher-layer protocol identification
• Deep packet inspection

The change is temporary and resets on reboot.

lessons.title: MAC Spoofing on Kali Linux
lessons.description: Use macchanger and manual methods on Linux

content.title: Check Current MAC Address
content.content: ifconfig

content.title: Disable Network Interface
content.content: ifconfig wlan1 down

content.title: Change to Random MAC
content.content: macchanger -r wlan1

content.title: Manual MAC Address Change
content.content:
ifconfig wlan0 down
ifconfig wlan0 hw ether 00:11:22:33:44:55
ifconfig wlan0 up

content.title: Verify MAC Address Change
content.content: ifconfig

content.title: Macchanger Options
content.content:
Useful macchanger options:
• -r: Random MAC address
• -a: Random MAC from same vendor
• -A: Random MAC from any vendor
• -p: Reset to permanent hardware MAC
• -s: Show current MAC address
• -l: List known vendors

lessons.title: MAC Spoofing on Windows
lessons.description: Use SMAC tool for Windows MAC address spoofing

content.title: SMAC Tool Overview
content.content: SMAC is a powerful and easy-to-use GUI tool for MAC address changing on Windows systems. It can activate a new MAC address automatically after changing it.

content.title: Download SMAC
content.content:
Download SMAC from: https://smac.soft32.com/

SMAC provides a user-friendly interface for:
• Viewing current MAC addresses
• Changing MAC addresses
• Generating random MAC addresses
• Restoring original MAC addresses

content.title: Using SMAC Tool
content.content:
SMAC operation steps:
1. Launch SMAC as administrator
2. Select the network adapter
3. Enter new MAC address or generate random
4. Click 'Update MAC' to apply changes
5. Restart network adapter if required

content.title: Verify Changes (Windows)
content.content: ipconfig /all

modules.title: Vulnerability Scanning Overview
modules.description: Introduction to vulnerability scanning tools and techniques

lessons.title: Vulnerability Scanning Fundamentals
lessons.description: Understanding vulnerability scanning principles and methodologies

content.title: What is Vulnerability Scanning?
content.content: Vulnerability scanning refers to auditing hosts, ports, and services running in a network to assess the security posture and search for security loopholes. It determines the possibility of network security attacks and evaluates systems for vulnerabilities such as missing patches, unnecessary services, weak authentication, and weak encryption.

content.title: Importance in Security Assessment
content.content:
Vulnerability scanning is a critical component of:
• Penetration testing assignments
• Security compliance audits
• Risk assessment processes
• Continuous security monitoring
• Patch management programs
• Security baseline establishment

content.title: Types of Vulnerability Scans
content.content:
Common scan types include:
• Network-based scanning
• Host-based scanning
• Wireless network scanning
• Application scanning
• Database scanning
• Web application scanning

lessons.title: Nessus Vulnerability Scanner
lessons.description: Comprehensive vulnerability assessment with Nessus

content.title: Nessus Scanner Overview
content.content: Nessus allows remote network auditing to determine if systems have been compromised or misconfigured. It provides comprehensive vulnerability detection and local machine auditing capabilities.

content.title: Nessus Capabilities
content.content:
Nessus can identify:
• Missing security patches
• Misconfigured systems
• Default passwords
• Unnecessary services
• Compliance violations
• Malware infections
• Network vulnerabilities

content.title: Getting Nessus
content.content:
Download from Tenable: https://www.tenable.com/downloads/nessus

Nessus offers different editions:
• Nessus Essentials (free for limited use)
• Nessus Professional

• Nessus Manager

lessons.title: Nikto Web Application Scanner

content.title: Nikto Web Scanner
content.content: Nikto is an Open Source web server scanner that performs comprehensive tests against web servers for multiple items, including over 6400 potentially dangerous files/CGIs, checks for outdated versions of over 1200 servers, and version-specific problems on over 270 servers.

content.title: Nikto Features
content.content:
Nikto scanning capabilities:
• Dangerous files and CGI detection
• Outdated server version identification
• Server configuration analysis
• Multiple index file detection
• HTTP server options enumeration
• Installed software identification
• Regular plugin and database updates

content.title: Basic Nikto Scan
content.content: nikto -h http://target-website.com

content.title: Nikto Source
content.content:
Official repository: https://github.com/sullo/nikto

Nikto is included in most penetration testing distributions and can be easily installed on various platforms.

modules.title: Introduction to System Hacking
modules.description: Foundational concepts in system hacking and computer security testing

lessons.title: System Hacking Fundamentals
lessons.description: Understanding the scope and methodology of system hacking

content.title: What is System Hacking?
content.content: System hacking is the science of testing computers and networks for vulnerabilities and harmful plug-ins. It involves the compromise of computer systems and software to gain access to target computers and steal or misuse their sensitive information. System hacking exploits weaknesses in computer systems and networks.

content.title: System Hacking Methodology
content.content:
The system hacking process typically follows these phases:
1. **Reconnaissance:** Information gathering about the target
2. **Scanning:** Identifying live systems and open ports
3. **Enumeration:** Extracting detailed information
4. **Vulnerability Assessment:** Identifying security weaknesses
5. **Exploitation:** Gaining unauthorized access
6. **Post-Exploitation:** Maintaining access and covering tracks

content.title: Common Attack Vectors
content.content:
System hackers exploit various attack vectors:
• Operating system vulnerabilities
• Application security flaws
• Network protocol weaknesses
• Misconfigurations
• Weak authentication mechanisms
• Social engineering
• Physical security gaps
• Insider threats

content.title: Ethical Hacking Principles
content.content:
Ethical hacking must follow strict guidelines:
• Obtain proper authorization before testing
• Respect scope and boundaries
• Minimize system disruption
• Maintain confidentiality
• Report findings responsibly
• Follow legal and regulatory requirements

lessons.title: System Components and Attack Surfaces
lessons.description: Identifying potential attack surfaces in computer systems

content.title: System Security Layers
content.content:
Computer systems have multiple security layers that can be targeted:
• **Hardware Layer:** Physical components and firmware
• **Operating System:** Kernel, drivers, and system services
• **Application Layer:** Software applications and services
• **Network Layer:** Communication protocols and services
• **User Layer:** Human factors and access controls

content.title: Common Hacking Targets
content.content:
System hackers typically target:
• User accounts and passwords
• Administrative privileges
• Network services and protocols
• Database systems
• Web applications
• Email systems
• File shares and storage
• Backup systems

content.title: Defense-in-Depth Strategy
content.content:
Effective system security requires multiple defensive layers:
• Perimeter security (firewalls, IDS/IPS)
• Network segmentation
• Access controls and authentication
• Endpoint protection
• Security monitoring and logging
• Incident response capabilities
• Security awareness training
• Regular security assessments
